courses.name: Land of the Pharaohs

cmCourseInfo.description: The course traces the history of ancient Egypt from the foundation of the Egyptian state around 3050 BCE to its incorporation into the Roman Empire. The focus is on various aspects of Egyptian culture, including the institution of kingship, the role of women, and the peculiarities of Egyptian art, literature, and religion. Emphasis is placed on the methods by which knowledge about this ancient civilization can be obtained.
cmCourseInfo.title: Land of the Pharaohs

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Heartland of Ancient Empires

cmCourseInfo.description: From city state to empire. The peoples and polities of Mesopotamia and the Near East, including Sumerians, Assyrians, Babylonians, and Persians. Their cultural contributions, from the development of writing to their achievements in law, administration, science, art and architecture, religion, and literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: Heartland of Ancient Empires

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is a fully online course that has both synchronous and asynchronous components. Attendance in two weekly discussion classes (Tuesday and Thursday 1–2pm EST) and one weekly tutorial via Blackboard Collaborate/Quercus is required, but all other content is uploaded for you to review in advance of the classes. Four slots will be available for the weekly tutorial (Thursday 2–3pm and 3–4 pm, Friday 10–11 am and 11am–12 pm EST). Audio equipment is required. A webcam is highly desirable but not obligatory.

courses.name: The Islamic World

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 28, 2020: Room added.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 28, 2020: Room added.

cmCourseInfo.description: What makes a certain thing (a state, art, law) Islamic? When and how did what we think about as the Islamic today come about? How has “the Islamic” changed over time? With these questions in mind, this course introduces students to major peoples, events, intellectual currents, and institutions in Islamic history.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Islamic World

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: The Biblical World

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 30, 2020: Delivery method changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: September 9, 2020: Room changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examine the history, lands, peoples, religions, literatures and cultures that produced the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament. Topics to be covered include an overview of the geography and history of Ancient Israel and Judea, the role of the Hebrew, Aramaic, and Greek languages, the literary genres reflected in biblical and some contemporary non-biblical texts, and the scholarly methods by which the Bible is studied.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Biblical World

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

NMC 104H1F Biblical World

 This is a flipped classroom + dual delivery course. Lectures will be given as 2-hrs online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for a dual-delivery in-class / webinar tutorial 1 hrs/week (Thursday 1-2p, 2-3p, and Friday 10-11a, 11-12p EST). Students participating in the tutorial remotely need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Rebels, Misfits, and Outcasts in Modern Arabic Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines modern Arabic literary works that portray marginalized social figures and groups, including the criminal, the urban poor, the peasantry, the delinquent, the prostitute, and the political outcast. Explores issues such as political violence, marginality, precarity, social reform and social exclusion. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Rebels, Misfits, and Outcasts in Modern Arabic Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need Quercus and the ability to use BlackBoard Collaborate.

courses.name: Law and Order in the Ancient Near East

cmCourseInfo.description: Are human beings basically evil or good? What creates order in society? Coercion? Religion? Can societies operate without law? This course explores different systems of authority and control through ancient texts, focusing on the very first ideas of law in human history. We examine actual law codes, court cases on real estate disputes and conspiracy to commit murder and rape, as well as alternative means of regulating communities such as ideology, ritual and magic. While most courses on ancient law approach the topic from the perspective of modern concerns, this course situates the first law in its own historical, social and political context. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Law and Order in the Ancient Near East

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an in-person or dual delivery course that has both synchronous and asynchronous components.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: Iranian Women Reveal their Lives: the First Generation

cmCourseInfo.description: The narrative of women speaking out begins in Iran in the first decades of the 20th century. In this course, we will look at an early generation of educated Iranian females who although from varied backgrounds have a common desire to make their lives public. We will refer to a mix of sources including memoirs, interviews and poems to explore how feminist aspirations are repressed or expressed in a society dominated by patriarchal values. We will analyse how a woman’s childhood experience affects her personal expectations for the future and whether the cultural environment restricted this generation or encouraged women to make a social contribution. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Iranian Women Reveal their Lives: the First Generation

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Seminars meet once a week for two hours Tuesdays 1-3 pm (previously scheduled) Students need to be able to use BLACKBOARD COLLABORATE (Ultra). Format is first hour for class discussion on BB collaborate based on assigned readings as outlined in the Course Syllabus. Online meeting for an hour is anticipated with next hour for further discussion using QUERCUS DISCUSSIONS facility. Assignments are delivered and returned using QUERCUS. Correspondence with students is by email: Students contact Instructor via utoronto email and Instructor contacts students using Quercus mail or Course Announcement page on Quercus. Arrangements will be made with u of t Library for availability of course readings online if in person use of library is not possible.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: Babylon: Fact vs. Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: The ancient city of Babylon, now a vast archaeological site in Iraq about 100km south of Baghdad, has captured people’s imagination up to this day. Who has not heard of the Hanging Gardens of Babylon, the Biblical Tower of Babel, or the sci-fi TV series Babylon 5? Yet, how much of that reflects the reality of ancient Babylon? This course will explore the city of Babylon through its texts and archaeology and contrast this data with the way the city has been remembered over the past two thousand years. However, the goal of the course is not only to investigate how myths about Babylon have been constructed throughout the centuries. It will also look at the shortcomings of contemporary academic research on Babylon, and how difficult it is to reconstruct humankind's distant past. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Babylon: Fact vs. Fiction

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Anthropology of the Middle East

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an introduction to the contemporary Middle East from an anthropological perspective. Topics will include gender, kinship, religion, modernity, popular culture, and the study of everyday life.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of the Middle East

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule.

courses.name: The Arabic Novel

cmCourseInfo.description: Focuses on the origins and development of the novel genre in the Arabic tradition. Examines the aesthetic qualities of the genre as an artistic form and the ways that it has depicted and intervened in the modern social, political, and cultural upheavals that have shaped the Arab world in the 20th century. Readings of novels and criticism in English.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Arabic Novel

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students need Quercus and the ability to use BlackBoard Collaborate.

courses.name: Ancient Bureaucracies

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey course on the evolution of bureaucracies in the ancient Near East (Iraq, Iran, Syria, Turkey, the Levant) and Egypt. Covering the period from 9,000 to 600 B.C.E, the course will track the development from simple storage and accounting procedures in Neolithic villages to administrative complexities in urban settings, leading to the advent of writing systems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Bureaucracies
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NMC102H1

Breadth Requirements: Society and its Institutions (3)

Distribution Requirements: Humanities

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2 hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1hr/week (Monday 12-1 p.m) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students need access to Adobe Acrobat (lecture materials will be provided as digital handouts) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Voices from Ancient Egypt

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to the culture of ancient Egypt through the study of 'functional' textual materials, including domestic, religious (including funerary and ritual), historical, and scientific texts, to paint a rich picture of the daily life and experiences of the ancient Egyptians. No knowledge of Egyptian required; all texts read in translation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Voices from Ancient Egypt

courses.name: Hebrew Bible

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the critical study of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament and the related literature of ancient Jewish communities (Apocrypha, Pseudepigrapha, Dead Sea Scrolls). English translations used; no knowledge of Hebrew is required. (Offered alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Hebrew Bible

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

NMC 252H1S Hebrew Bible 

This is a flipped classroom + dual delivery course. Lectures will be given as 2-hrs online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for a dual-delivery in-class / webinar class 2 hrs/week (Thursday 12–2p EST). Students participating in the Thursday meeting remotely need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). 

 

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: Love, Battle, and Wit: Classics of Premodern Arabic Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Students read closely classic works in translation, through class discussion, in-class exercises, and short essays. Readings include: narratives like Kalila wa-Dimna and Ibn Hazm's love treatise; poems by Labid, Jarir, Abu Nuwas, al-Mutanabbi, and Ibn Nubata; and an obscene shadow play by Ibn Daniyal.
cmCourseInfo.title: Love, Battle, and Wit: Classics of Premodern Arabic Literature

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

NMC255H1F This is an online, synchronous course. Class time (Tuesdays and Thursdays, 1-2 pm) will be a combination of mini-lectures and directed discussions of the primary source readings, in breakout groups. Mini-lectures will be recorded for later study. Participation in the breakout groups during class time is mandatory. Students need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: The Archaeology of Gods, Ghosts, Witches and Demons

cmCourseInfo.description: This class investigates archaeological traces of human interaction with the supernatural world in the ancient Near East, including figurines, temples, skulls, statues, and cylinder seals. In order to contextualize different ways of thinking about other worlds, we also look at cross-cultural comparisons ranging from Africa to the Americas.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Archaeology of Gods, Ghosts, Witches and Demons
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NMC102H1

Breadth Requirements: Thought, Belief and Behaviour (2)

Distribution Requirements: Humanities

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

 Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. The content of each week’s module will be uploaded to Quercus for the student to view as they wish. This will constitute half of the course hours. For the remaining time students will work in groups under instructors’ mentorship to research and solve problems associated with each module. Mentorship will take place via weekly discussions (multiple timeslots offered) conducted either on Blackboard Collaborate/Quercus or in person. Audio equipment is required. A camera is highly desirable but not necessary.

courses.name: The Archaeology of Stuff

cmCourseInfo.description: Discover how the structure of animal skin enables the making of leather and tattoos; why mighty kings boasted about tree-cutting expeditions; how chariots, stirrups, and gunpowder changed the very structure of contemporary societies; why spears are better than swords. Understand and appreciate the materials in the world around you.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Archaeology of Stuff

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given as a series of relatively short videos that should collectively equal two lectures a week. These may be viewed asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for an online webinar tutorial presently scheduled on Thursday sometime between 4-6 pm, planned to be through Quercus. Other times (including the evening) and venues (Skype, Zoom, Outlook) may be possible if there is student demand.

courses.name: Archaeology in War Zones: Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan

cmCourseInfo.description: Focusing on Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan, this course raises some controversial issues in coming to grips with the impact of war on retrieving, interpreting, and preserving the past. Find out the many ways we can work to preserve the history and culture of places at risk, now and in the future.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeology in War Zones: Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Students need

courses.name: Early Islamic History: The Prophet and the Caliphates

cmCourseInfo.description: Builds a solid foundation in Middle East & Islamic Studies, giving students an understanding of major themes and events, movements and individuals in early Islamic history and an awareness of the tools and sources available for study, problems historians have encountered in using them, and interpretive approaches to these sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Islamic History: The Prophet and the Caliphates

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students will also have the opportunity to schedule additional online meetings for questions and clarifications. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: The Turks in History: From Nomads of the Steppe Frontier to Islamic Rulers

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the roles of Turks as raiders, migrants, slave-soldiers, and empire-builders in the formation of the Islamic world prior to the Ottomans (1300). Readings include primary sources in translation on the Islamization of the Turks in Central Asia and their gradual takeover of Iranian and Arab lands.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Turks in History: From Nomads of the Steppe Frontier to Islamic Rulers

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2 hours live-stream and recorded. Online office hours by appointment. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Introduction to the Modern Middle East

cmCourseInfo.description: The emergence of modern states in the Middle East, against a background of empire, world wars, and national and religious movements. Students will learn why the modern map looks the way it does, and how Middle Eastern peoples' self-identifications have changed over the past 200 years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Modern Middle East

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recorded lectures will be posted online, ca. 2 hours of lectures per week, at the beginning of each week. On Thursdays from 10:30 to 11:30 there will be a live, synchronous discussion of the week’s lectures and readings with the instructor and/or TA(s). Students are expected to be logged in and present for the online discussions.

courses.name: Topics in Judaism and Feminism: Conflict, Competition, Complement

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the interaction between Jewish religious and secular movements and feminism, focusing on conflicts between Jewish law (halakhah) and ideas of egalitarianism, particularly in legal disabilities for women connected to marriage and divorce, lack of access to high-level Torah study, and discrimination in public religious roles. Examines competition among the movements to include women in Torah study has led to, and the extent to which inclusion and egalitarianism have become a complement in Judaism. (Offered in alternate years, topic changes)
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Judaism and Feminism: Conflict, Competition, Complement

courses.name: Introduction to Coptic Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Overview of the history of the Copts from political, religious, social and economic perspectives. Literary and documentary sources will illustrate these different aspects of Coptic Civilization. The focus on Coptic Monasticism will underline the role of monasteries as conservers of the Coptic Orthodox Church tradition.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Coptic Studies

courses.name: Farmers to Pyramid Builders: Cultural and Political History of Ancient Egypt I

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploration of the primary archaeological, architectural, and inscriptional sources, questioning and analyzing ideas about Egypt's development from farming communities at the dawn of history to an early state that built great pyramids for its kings, collapsed into civil war, and grew to become a colonizing power in the Middle Kingdom.
cmCourseInfo.title: Farmers to Pyramid Builders: Cultural and Political History of Ancient Egypt I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 5 FCE in any field or 1 FCE in NMC

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course with an interactive webinar component. Lectures will be given as 2hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will also participate in synchronous online webinar class 2hrs/week (Thursdays 12-2pm EST) in which we will discuss topics introduced in the lectures, debate interpretations, and explore some of the sources that have been used to reconstruct ancient Egyptian cultural history. We will also discuss and work through approaches to the course assignments. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Hyksos Subjects to Empire Builders: Cultural and Political History of Ancient Egypt II

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploration of the primary archaeological, architectural, and inscriptional sources, questioning interpretations and analyzing how Egypt confronted foreign domination and developed into a major empire in the New Kingdom under Thutmose III, Hatshepsut, Akhenaten, and Ramesses II, then fragmented politically in the Third Intermediate Period and ultimately became a colony itself.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hyksos Subjects to Empire Builders: Cultural and Political History of Ancient Egypt II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 5 FCE in any field or 1 FCE in NMC

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course with an interactive webinar component. Lectures will be given as 2hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will also participate in synchronous online webinar class 2hrs/week (Thursdays 12-2pm EST) in which we will discuss topics introduced in the lectures, debate interpretations, and explore some of the sources that have been used to reconstruct ancient Egyptian cultural history. We will also discuss and work through approaches to the course assignments. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: History of Iran: From the Sasanians to the Safavids

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the political history and cultural legacy of the Sasanian empire and transmission of Persian concepts of kingship, administration, and social organization into Islamic civilization, Perso-Islamic cultural synthesis under the Samanids, the interaction between nomadic and sedentary cultures under the rule of Turkic and Turko-Mongolian dynasties, and the Safavid state.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Iran: From the Sasanians to the Safavids
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any half-credit course in the history of the ancient or early Islamic world offered by academic units within the Faculty of Arts & Science

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course delivered per the meeting schedule. Lectures will be given synchronously via BbCollaborate/Quercus. Tutorials will be held synchronously via BbCollaborate/Quercus as a forum for class discussion and review of the week’s lecture.

courses.name: Christian Literature from the Middle East in Translation

cmCourseInfo.description: Survey of various literary genres from works produced by Armenian, Coptic, Maronite, Melkite, and Syriac authors between the 3rd and the 19th centuries CE. Genres include theology in poetry, biblical commentaries, historiography and chronicles, hagiography, songs and epics, apologetics, and travel accounts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christian Literature from the Middle East in Translation

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 2hrs/week (Tuesday 4-6 pm EST), and the ability to ask questions and clarifications about the lectures. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Dead Sea Scrolls

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an examination of the historical and cultural context in which the Dead Sea Scrolls were authored and copied, the types of writings included in the Scrolls, and the ancient Jewish groups behind these texts. It also discusses the significance of the Scrolls for understanding the textual development of the Hebrew Bible, ancient scriptural interpretation, and the thought world of the Jews during the period that gave birth to both Rabbinic Judaism and early Christianity. No knowledge of Hebrew or Aramaic is required. (Offered alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Dead Sea Scrolls

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course with some asynchronous components. Attendance in a weekly discussion class on Mondays at 12 pm EST via Blackboard Collaborate/Quercus is required, but all other content is uploaded for you to review prior to the webinar. Audio equipment is required. A camera is highly desirable but not necessary.

courses.name: Ancient Egyptian Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: Focuses on analysis of examples of the different genres of ancient Egyptian literary texts, including wisdom literature, poetry, literary narratives, and mythical tales. We question how to define literature and discuss how literary texts developed in pharaonic Egypt. No knowledge of ancient Egyptian is required; all texts read in translation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ancient Egyptian Literature
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any H course (0.5 FCE) on ancient Egypt offered by academic units within the Faculty of Arts & Science

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Possible Worlds: Arabic Speculative Fiction

cmCourseInfo.description: Arabic speculative fiction from the medieval to the modern period, discussed with attention to early Arabic novel’s adaptation of the medieval maqama genre, and the relation between speculative fiction and political and social critique. Texts include al-Ma`arri, Ibn Shuhayd, maqamat, al-Muwaylihi, science fiction, and dystopic novels and conceptual art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Possible Worlds: Arabic Speculative Fiction

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: The Ottoman Empire in the Age of Reform, 1808-1918

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 31, 2020: Course cancelled.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 31, 2020: Course cancelled.

cmCourseInfo.description: The last phase of the Ottoman empire has long been viewed by Orientalists and Middle East nationalists as a period of inevitable decline. More recently, cultural historians of the Middle East have framed the long 19th. century as a period of grand reforms - or Tanzimat. This course seeks to critically examine the notions of reform of the state and reform of the individual between Sultan Mahmud IIs accession and the defeat of the Ottoman empire in World War I. Focusing largely on Istanbul and the Ottoman capitals political relations with the Arab provinces, we will relate economic, social and intellectual transformations to state laws and policies, Mediterranean capitalism and the rise of sectarianism and nationalism in the Middle East.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Ottoman Empire in the Age of Reform, 1808-1918

courses.name: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Middle Eastern Cultures

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines questions of gender and sexuality in the broader Middle East (Iran, Turkey, and the Arab world) from the colonial period to the present through readings of religious, cultural, historical, and literary texts. Focuses on the development of modern secular and religious feminist thought, cultural representations of gender and sexuality, and critical approaches to theorizing gender and sexuality in the Middle East.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Middle Eastern Cultures

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Nomads in the Ancient Near East

cmCourseInfo.description: Using ancient archaeological and textual sources as well as modern ethnographies and political theories, this class takes a critical look at the role of mobile populations in Near Eastern history from the fourth to first millennium BCE, assessing modern perspectives as well as the ancient evidence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Nomads in the Ancient Near East
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NMC102H1

Breadth Requirements: Society and its Institutions (3)

Distribution Requirements: Humanities

courses.name: Life Cycle and Personal Status in Judaism

cmCourseInfo.description: The course explores Jewish attitudes to various personal status issues, utilizing material from biblical and rabbinic sources to modern Jewish positions. The specific topics covered vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Life Cycle and Personal Status in Judaism

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the relations among the various ethno-religious communities in the Ottoman Empire from the 14th century until 1922.
cmCourseInfo.title: Muslims, Christians, and Jews in the Ottoman Empire
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NMC241H1, NMC275H1, NMC278H1, or NMC283Y1

Breadth Requirements: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)

courses.name: Iconography of the Art and Material Culture of the Islamic World

cmCourseInfo.description: The art and material culture of the Islamic world is rich in iconography - from Persian paintings to Afghan war rugs - with complex layers of meaning that are not necessarily understood at first glance. Such imagery can be comprehended through numerous lenses, from pre-Islamic concepts and literary themes to politically-driven motivations or religious beliefs and practices. Through a series of case studies of examples of painting, ceramics, metalwork, textiles, and contemporary art, the course examines the meanings behind the iconography on objects from across the Middle East and Central Asia, dating from the medieval period to the present day.
cmCourseInfo.title: Iconography of the Art and Material Culture of the Islamic World

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: Sacred and Secular Spaces: Mesopotamian Architecture in Context

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of Mesopotamian architecture (temples, palaces, neighbourhoods) in settlements contexts, from the earliest villages to the large urban centres of Sumer, Babylonia, and Assyria (10,000-300 BC).
cmCourseInfo.title: Sacred and Secular Spaces: Mesopotamian Architecture in Context

courses.name: Research Seminar on Ancient Jewish Literature

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: A seminar focusing on the critical analysis of the Hebrew Bible and related ancient Jewish texts. Literary genre and critical topics will vary according to instructor’s research interests. Focus will be given to developing research skills by working with accepted critical methodologies. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. (Offered every 3 years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Seminar on Ancient Jewish Literature
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the instructor is required.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

NMC 450H1S Research Seminar on Ancient Jewish Literature: The Book of Ezekiel (Grad: NMC 1308H1s Reading in Hebrew Bible: The Book of Ezekiel) This is a flipped classroom + dual delivery course. Lectures will be given as 2-hrs online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for a dual-delivery in-class / webinar class 2 hrs/week (Thursday 9–11 EST). Students participating in the Thursday meeting remotely need the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: Seminar in Egyptian Archaeology I

cmCourseInfo.description: Seminar focuses on the social and cultural development of Egypt from the Predynastic Period through the Middle Kingdom, engaging with major theories regarding social complexity, state formation, urbanism, social organization, and regionalism. An independent research project and hands-on experience with artifacts at the ROM are important features of the course. (Offered every 3 years.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Egyptian Archaeology I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NMC101H1 or NMC343H1 or permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course that continues the tradition of seminar format through webinars. Students will attend online webinar meetings 2hrs/week (Tuesdays 2-4pm EST) in which they will lead and participate in discussions of topics introduced in the course readings and debates about controversial issues, focusing on themes in ancient Egyptian cultural development and the archaeological data that relates to these developments. They will also develop individual research projects in conjunction with the professor, and will prepare presentations that will be posted for asynchronous viewing by course participants and discussion in the webinars. Students need PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra)

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Near and Middle Eastern Civilizations

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced seminar organized around readings on a topic selected by the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Near and Middle Eastern Civilizations

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Intellectuals of the Modern Arab World

cmCourseInfo.description: The course is designed to re-examine the role of intellectuals in the Arab world and political events that shaped their thinking. It introduces the life and thought of some leading thinkers of the Arab world and relates their thought to the lived experience of political, social, economic and cultural change in the Middle East. Intended for upper year students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intellectuals of the Modern Arab World

courses.name: Modern Turkey

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar examines the history and politics of Turkey since 1923. It explores issues such as the Ottoman roots of Turkey’s early leadership, the establishment of the republic, Ataturk’s reforms and legacy, internal political and social transformations, and the country’s changing geopolitical role. The course also explores some aspects of Turkish literature and culture. No knowledge of Turkish is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Turkey

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Tutorials will be delivered online; learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule.

courses.name: Nationalism in the Arab World

cmCourseInfo.description: A seminar that critically examines the types and varieties of national expression in Arab societies of the Middle East and North Africa, through a reading of common texts and students' individual research projects. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Nationalism in the Arab World

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The seminar will meet for live discussions every Wednesday beginning at 1:00 (1:10) to discuss the week’s readings and to hear student presentations. Students are expected to be logged in and present for the class sessions.

courses.name: Mesopotamian Material Culture: Art and Artifacts

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on a comprehensive introduction and discussion of Mesopotamian artwork from the Neolithic to the Iron Age periods (ca. 6000 - 300 BCE). Following an introduction of major artifact classes (including sculpture, relief, and glyptics [seals and sealings]), students will learn to describe and catalogue works of Mesopotamian art, allowing them to critically use and evaluate primary and secondary publications. Systematic descriptions and labels for key characteristics such as the object materials, size, iconography, genre, style, and theme will be established to show how meaningful artifact typologies can be constructed. The potential as well as limitations of art-historical approaches for archaeological work, especially for the chronology and interpretation of archeological contexts, will be discussed and examined on selected cases. Several classes will be taught at the Royal Ontario Museum to demonstrate the handling and physical analysis of artifacts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mesopotamian Material Culture: Art and Artifacts

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2 hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1hr/week (Friday 12-1 p.m) to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students need access to Adobe Acrobat (lecture materials will be provided as digital handouts) and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

courses.name: Independent Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: Open only when an NMC full-time faculty member is willing and available to supervise. Student must find an appropriate NMC supervisor for the desired topic and obtain the approval of the departmental Associate Chair/Undergraduate Coordinator. Obtain details and a course form from the Department Undergraduate Administrator. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Studies

courses.name: Senior Thesis

cmCourseInfo.description: A 40-60 page (15,000-20,000 word) research paper (100% of the final mark) written under the supervision of a full-time NMC faculty member. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4th year status in NMC Specialist program; supervisor's approval; departmental approval.
